popText.text: Facilitation payments are low-value, unofficial fees paid to public officials to encourage them to do their job properly or promptly.
In some countries, facilitation payments are part of doing business, but that doesn’t make them right.
The Johnson Controls policy prohibits facilitation or “grease” payments. Never make a facilitation payment, even if it’s a small amount.

revealCallOut.buttonText: A transaction involving a government official

popText.text: There can be legitimate fees for some Government actions, like paying a fee for a permit.
But we must be very careful of any financial transactions related to government officials and ensure that any payments made are legitimate and properly documented and receipted.

There are strict bribery laws that prohibit us from giving anything of value to a government official. Paying unofficial fees, or being unable to adequately justify a payment to a Government official could lead to allegations of bribery which could result in significant fines or prosecution for the company and the individuals involved.

revealCallOut.buttonText: Pressure to move forward without all the facts

popText.text: Signs of bribery can come up without warning, in high-stress situations where there is pressure to act immediately without all of the facts.
Jian should have recognized signs of potential bribery and resisted the pressure to act or decide until he could be sure that the transaction was appropriate and allowed.

Even though the supplier were the ones who paid the bribe and we were unaware of it and did not approve it, Johnson Controls could be held liable because the bribe was paid on the company's behalf and it benefitted from it.
